summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney to colleagues, including Alex Acosta, describing emotional interviews with three victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The prosecutor details the victims' trauma, their reaction to a reported 18-month plea deal for Epstein, and their desire for significant jail time over restitution. The email also mentions the FBI's victim-witness coordinator arranging counseling and plans to interview four more victims.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Recipient of the email discussing the victim interviews and the Epstein case. He is a key legal official involved in the prosecution decisions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation. Victims expressed fear of him and anger about a potential 18-month plea deal.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was involved in the prosecutorial decisions regarding the case against Epstein.

events.title: Victim Interviews Described
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney describes conducting emotional interviews with three victims of Jeffrey Epstein, during which one victim broke down sobbing multiple times and another expressed anger about a reported 18-month plea deal.

events.title: Planned Additional Victim Interviews
events.description: The email states that four more victims are scheduled to be interviewed the following day.

locations: 500 S. Australian Ave, Suite 400 West Palm Beach, FL 33401
keyFacts: Victims of Jeffrey Epstein were interviewed and displayed severe emotional trauma, including one having nightmares about Epstein coming after her.
A victim expressed strong opposition to a reported 18-month plea deal for Epstein, stating she would prefer he spend significant time in jail over receiving any restitution money.
The FBI's victim-witness coordinator was involved and had arranged counseling for several of the victims.

The email is addressed to Alex Acosta, who was the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida at the time and would later be central to the controversial non-prosecution agreement for Epstein.
